thread.title: Mail Online digital advertising slows down to 16% annual growth | Media
thread.title_full: Mail Online digital advertising slows down to 16% annual growth | Media | The Guardian

title: Mail Online digital advertising slows down to 16% annual growth | Media
text:
Mail Online has reported digital advertising growth of 16% in the 11 months to the end of August, a significant slowdown on the almost 50% rate of growth seen a year ago.
Parent company Daily Mail & General Trust said Mail Online has reported ad revenue growth of 16% year on year, a £9m revenue increase, in the year to date.
This compares with a growth rate of 49% reported for approximately the same period last year .

The slowdown prompted analysts at Exane to publish a note to investors earlier this month warning that Mail Online was likely to miss its stated revenue target of £100m by the end of next year .
“We see the recent revenue slowdown of Mail Online (despite strong audience growth) as more structural than cyclical, with mobile, ad blocking and social media all bringing new challenges to monetisation,” said William Packer, analyst at Exane. “We now expect Mail Online to miss their £100m revenue target.”
For the full year to the end of September 2014 Mail Online reported 41% revenue growth to £62m , beating its target of £60m.
The company is aiming to make £80m in revenue for the year to the end of September 2015, although it has said that this is not a “hard target”.
DMGT said that total underlying advertising revenues across Mail Online, the Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday were down 5% for the year to the end of August. 

The newspaper titles have seen ad revenues fall 9% in the 11 months to the end of August.
